description.p: The slender elf cleans his glasses with the corner of his cloak as the dust settles around him. He was the first person to set foot in this ancient temple in hundreds of years. His benefactor had paid him a great deal to find this place, and after months of pouring over forgotten tomes he had finally figured out it’s long lost location. Now he had a choice to make, would he report back to his benefactor so they could strip the temple of it’s valuables? Or would he keep it’s location hidden, and preserve the knowledge found here himself? For to a savant, knowledge is more precious than gold coins.

The elderly warrior assessed the state of his men, they were exhausted and almost out of supplies. This was the tenth day of the siege, and the warrior knew at this point no relief was coming. He was too old to be of use in battle, but if his men followed his orders to the letter, and without hesitation, they just might still have a fighting chance. He stood up, and for what may be the last time, drew his sword.

A young dwarf bends over his unconscious comrade in the midst of battle, his hands shaking as he examines the unconscious dwarf’s wounds. His clan had spent a great deal of their fortune to send him to the best university gold could buy. All those hours spent in lectures, libraries, and observation; all for this moment. He thought back to what he had learned about field medicine from his professors and began to dress the dwarf’s wounds.

There are many intelligent people in the world, but few are true savants. Born with with an innate desire to learn all they can, and the potential for a genius level intellect, they spend their lives studying anything that those around them are willing to teach them. Savants are often recognized at an early age, and in their hunger for knowledge, they are drawn to great libraries and universities. They will do anything to access the troves of knowledge that lie in hidden in forbidden places, for savants, no price is too steep to pay for knowledge.

Despite their aptitude for learning, most savants seek to better themselves without having to rely on others. Savants reject the patronage of gods and other powerful beings, and in turn they view wizardry as a path for the weak willed. Relying on their great minds alone, they strive for perfection.

Savants tend to be hyper focused on their chosen area of expertise. They obsess over it, learning all they can about the subject. Once they reach the climax of learning in that specialty and there is nothing anyone else can teach them, they do not move on. Instead they will go to great lengths, risking life and limb, to advance their chosen field of study.

Often doing so at great cost to themselves, savants will not stop researching, experimenting, and theorizing until they have made an indelible mark in their academic discipline. A savants ultimate goal in life is to discover some previously unknown truth about the universe.

You can make a Savant quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Intelligence, followed by Wisdom . Second, choose either the noble or sage background from the Player’s Handbook.
As a savant, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per savant level after 1st
Weapons: Simple weapons and hand crossbows
Tools: One set of artisan’s tools of your choice
Skills: Choose three from Arcana, History, Insight, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, Persuasion, Religion, and Sleight of Hand.

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: any two simple weapons of your choice
one set of artisan’s tools of your choice
leather armor and a scholar’s pack

tr.td: Adriot Fighter, Intellect Points, Information Recall

div.p: If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player’s Handbook, here’s what you need to know if you choose the savant as one of your classes.

Ability Score Minimum. As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 in both Intelligence and Wisdom to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a savant.
Proficiencies Gained. If savant isn’t your initial class, you gain two skill proficiencies from the savant list when you take your first level in this class.

setters.set: An Intelligence-based class with an innate desire to learn.
If savant isn’t your initial class, you gain two skill proficiencies from the savant list when you take your first level in this class.

description.p: At 1st level, your insightful way of fighting grants you some measure of protection. When wearing light armor, you can use your Intelligence modifier in place of your Dexterity modifier when calculating your Armor Class.

Additionally, your sharp mind allows you to land strikes where the enemy is weakest. You may use your Intelligence modifier in place of Strength or Dexterity for attack rolls as long as you are proficient with the weapon.

sheet.description: You may use your Intelligence modifier in place of Strength or Dexterity for attack rolls as long as you are proficient with the weapon.

description.p: At 1st level, you are able use your lightning fast observational skills to aid your allies in combat. You have a number of Intellect Points that you can use to fuel your savant abilities. You have a number of Intellect Points equal to your savant level + your Intelligence modifier + your Wisdom modifier.
Once you expend all of your intellect points you need to take time to rest your mind and relax. You regain all spent intellect points when you complete a short or long rest.
Some of your Intellect Point features require the target to make a saving throw to resist the feature's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

center.p: Intellect Save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

description.p: Some savant abilities allow you to expend more then one Intellect Point, up to your mental limit. Your mental limit is the amount of exertion that your mind can take at one time. Your mental limit is equal to your Intelligence modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

sheet.description: Your Intellect Save DC is {{intellect:save-dc}}. Your Mental Limit is {{intellect-points:mental-limit}} Intellect Points.

description.p: At 1st level, as a reaction, when you roll for any Intelligence based skill check, or are forced make an Intelligence saving throw, you can choose expend a number of Intellect Points, up to your mental limit, to increase your roll. Roll a d6 for each Intellect Point you expend and add the result to the skill check or saving throw.
You must choose to expend the Intellect Points before you see the result of your roll.

sheet.description: When you roll for any Intelligence based skill check, or are forced make an Intelligence saving throw, you can choose expend up to {{intellect-points:mental-limit}} Intellect Points to increase your roll. Roll a d6 for each Intellect Point you expend and add the result to the skill check or saving throw. You must choose to expend the Intellect Points before you see the result of your roll.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, you can use a bonus action on your turn to expend one or more Intellect Points to mark an enemy creature, highlighting it’s weak points for you and your allies. The next creature to deal damage to the marked creature with a weapon attack, rolls a d6 for each Intellect Point you expended, adding the result to their damage roll.

If you take damage before the enemy creature you marked is hit with a weapon attack, you must make a concentration saving throw, to maintain concentration (as you would to concentrate on a spell). On a failure you can no longer concentrate on highlighting the creatures weak points, your ability fails, and any Intellect Points you expended are wasted.

sheet.description: You expend one or more Intellect Points to mark an enemy creature, highlighting it’s weak points for you and your allies. The next creature to deal damage to the marked creature with a weapon attack, rolls a d6 for each Intellect Point you expended, adding the result to their damage roll. If you take damage before the enemy creature you marked is hit with a weapon attack, you must make a concentration saving throw, to maintain concentration (as you would to concentrate on a spell).

description.p: At 3rd level, choose your academic discipline. This is your chosen field of study, and you have devoted your life to learning all there is to know about this field. Choose one of the following Academic Disciplines; Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, or Tactician.
Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level, and they are detailed at the end of this class description.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

At 5th level, you can use a bonus action on your turn to make an Intelligence check to analyze a creature you can see. Choose one fact you would like to learn about the enemy creature; an ability score, immunity, resistance, vulnerability, language, sense, skill, or armor class. Make an intelligence check (use an applicable skill if appropriate), the DC is equal to 5 + the creature’s Challenge Rating. On a success you surmise the information about the creature.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier. You regain all uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You can make an Intelligence check to analyze a creature you can see. You learn one fact: an ability score, immunity, resistance, vulnerability, language, sense, skill, or armor class. Make an intelligence check (use an applicable skill if appropriate), the DC is equal to 5 + the creature’s Challenge Rating. On a success you surmise the information about the creature.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, you can refocus your mind and clear away any distracting thoughts. As an action on your turn, you can regain a number of spent Intellect Points equal to 1d6 + your Intelligence modifier.
Once you use this ability you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.

sheet.description: You can regain 1d6 + {{intelligence:modifier}} Intellect Points.

description.p: At 7th level, your lightning fast ability to process the world around you makes it impossible to catch you off guard. You have advantage on initiative rolls, and you are immune to the surprised condition.

sheet.description: You have advantage on initiative rolls, and you are immune to the surprised condition.

description.p: By 11th level, your knowledge of your areas of expertise is nearly perfect. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your Proficiency Bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

sheet.description: Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your Proficiency Bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

description.p: At 14th level, your mastery over your own mind grants you supernatural perceptive abilities. As an action while conscious, you can expend 5 Intellect Points to you gain the following benefits for one minute:

ul.li: Your passive perception cannot be less than 20.
You gain Truesight out to 30 ft.
You notice secret doors hidden by magic within 30 ft.
You can see into the Ethereal Plane out to 30ft.

sheet.description: You gain the following benefits for one minute: your passive perception is at least 20; you gain Truesight to 30 feet; you notice secret doors hidden by magic within 30 feet; and you can see into the Ethereal Plane out to 30 feet.

description.p: At 15th level, your mastery over your mind allows you to command your body to react in ways beyond your normal capabilities. As a reaction, when you are forced to make a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you may expend an Intellect Point to add your Intelligence modifier to the result of the saving throw.

sheet.description: When you are forced to make a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you may expend an Intellect Point to add {{intelligence:modifier}} to the result of the saving throw.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, your advanced mental abilities allow you predict enemy attacks before they happen. It is impossible for attack rolls to have advantage against you while you aren't incapacitated.

sheet.description: It is impossible for attack rolls to have advantage against you while you aren't incapacitated.

description.p: At 20th level, your intellect grows far beyond mortal limits, increasing to legendary levels. Your Intelligence and Wisdom scores each increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

The Naturalist's classroom begins at the very edges of civilization. They study the environments, flora, and fauna that live beyond the influence of civilized peoples. They are experts at anticipating weather patterns, predicting the movements of herds of wild animals, and knowing the difference between an edible plant and a toxic one.

Naturalists are highly sought after to guides for adventuring parties. They can safely navigate dangerous environments; arid deserts, jagged mountain ranges, and treacherous jungles, the naturalist is at home in all.

At 3rd level your choice to dedicate yourself to the study of nature and all the plants and animals of the natural world grants you a unique insight into the ways of the wild. When you choose this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency in the nature skill. If you already have proficiency in nature you gain expertise, which means you add double your proficiency bonus to any nature checks you make.
Additionally, you ignore difficult terrain caused by natural features, and you cannot become lost while in a natural environment as long as you can see the sky.

sheet.description: You ignore difficult terrain caused by natural features, and you cannot become lost while in a natural environment as long as you can see the sky

description.p: Starting at 3rd level, your specialization as a Naturalist makes you an invaluable guide in the wilds. As an action on your turn you may expend an Intellect Point to educate a friendly creature and grant them one of the following effects for ten minutes:
Animal Tamer. The creature gains proficiency in the animal handling skill and has advantages on rolls to maintain control of their mount.
Diver. The creatures gains a swim speed equal to their movement speed and they can hold their breath a number of minutes equal to three times their Constitution score.
Enhanced Movement. The creature's movement speed increases by 10 ft., and it only costs them 5 ft. of movement to get up from the prone condition.
Mountaineer. The creature gains a climb speed equal to their movement speed, and they reduce any falling damage they take by an amount equal to your savant level.
Natural Camouflage. The creature gains proficiency in the stealth skill and has advantage on rolls to hide in natural environments.
Tracker. The creature gains proficiency in the survival skill, and has advantage on rolls to track a creature they have seen in the past hour.

A creature can only be under one of these effects at a time. If you grant them the benefits of a new effect, the previous one immediately ends. As you gain savant levels, this ability to help others survive in the wild becomes more potent. At 9th level, these effects last for 1 hour, and at 13th level these effects last until the end of the creature's next long rest.

sheet.description: You may educate a friendly creature and grant them one of the following effects for ten minutes: Animal Tamer, Diver, Enhanced Movement, Mountaineer, Natural Camouflage, or Tracker. A creature can only be under one of these effects at a time.

You may educate a friendly creature and grant them one of the following effects for ten minutes: Animal Tamer, Diver, Enhanced Movement, Mountaineer, Natural Camouflage, or Tracker. A creature can only be under one of these effects at a time.

You may educate a friendly creature and grant them one of the following effects until the end of the creature's next long rest: Animal Tamer, Diver, Enhanced Movement, Mountaineer, Natural Camouflage, or Tracker. A creature can only be under one of these effects at a time.

description.p: Starting at 9th level, your time spent learning about the natural flora and fauna has enamored them to you. When a beast, monstrosity, or plant attacks you, as a reaction you may expend one Intellect Point and force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack.

sheet.description: When a beast, monstrosity, or plant attacks you, you can force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack.

description.p: At 13th level, you've come to understand the animals of the natural world in a way that few civilized peoples do. As an action on your turn you can touch a beast and attempt to charm it as if casting the dominate beast spell.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier. You regain all uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You can touch a beast and attempt to charm it as if casting the dominate beast spell.

description.p: By 17th level, you have become one of the leading authorities on the natural world. At the end of a short or long rest, you can attune yourself to one of the following natural environments: arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, jungle, mountain, swamp, or underdark. While in that environment you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You gain the benefits of all of your Outdoorsman effects.
You add your Intelligence modifier to your initiative rolls.
You have advantage on Intelligence and Wisdom checks related to the environment you are attuned to.

sheet.description: At the end of a short or long rest, you can attune yourself to one of the following natural environments: arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, jungle, mountain, swamp, or underdark. While in that environment you gain the following benefits: you gain the benefits of all of your Outdoorsman effects; you add {{intelligence:modifier}} to your initiative rolls; you have advantage on Intelligence and Wisdom checks related to the environment you are attuned to.

description.p: Philosophy is the purest of the Academic Disciplines that a savant can pursue. They spend their lives pondering the deep questions of existence. What is the purpose of life? Why did the gods create the multiverse? What is the nature of the material plane and the planes that surround it?

Through their study of mathematics, physics, natural sciences, and public speaking, they seek to perfect their knowledge of reality and their place in it. Philosophers make invaluable advisors and thinkers when they are on your side. They range from the humble village elders to the advisors of great kings.

Starting at 3rd level, your time spent studying the fundamental nature of knowledge has provided you with great insights into the world. When you choose this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency in both the Arcana and Religion skills. If you already have proficiency in one of those skills you gain expertise, which means you add double your proficiency bonus to any check you make with that skill.

Additionally, your time studying the nature of existence allows you to gain additional types of information with your Savant's Analysis feature. You can now use your Savant's Analysis to attempt to learn the target's alignment, creature type, plane of origin, or spellcasting ability (if it has one).

sheet.description: You can now use your Savant's Analysis to attempt to learn the target's alignment, creature type, plane of origin, or spellcasting ability (if it has one).

description.p: At 3rd level, your mastery over the spoken word allows you to twist your speech in such a way that it sows confusion in the minds of your enemies. As an action on your turn, expend an Intellect Point and force a creature within 30 ft., that can hear to you, to make an Intelligence saving throw against your Intellect save DC. On a failure, they become confused and distracted, and the next attack to target that creature before the beginning of your next turn has advantage.

As a bonus action when you use this ability, you can expend a number of additional Intellect Points, up to your Intelligence modifier, to target more creatures with your Confounding Theorem. For each Intellect Point you expend, you can target one additional creature as long as they are within 30 ft., and can hear you.

sheet.description: You force a creature within 30 ft., that can hear to you, to make an Intelligence saving throw against your Intellect save DC. On a failure, they become confused and distracted, and the next attack to target that creature before the beginning of your next turn has advantage. As a bonus action when you use this ability, you can expend a number of additional Intellect Points, up to your Intelligence modifier, to target more creatures with your Confounding Theorem. For each Intellect Point you expend, you can target one additional creature as long as they are within 30 ft., and can hear you.

description.p: At 9th level, you have spent much time contemplating your existence and your place in the universe. Your confidence in your purpose is unwavering. You gain proficiency in Charisma saving throws.
Additionally, you are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell while you are conscious.

sheet.description: You are always under the effects of the protection from evil and good spell while you are conscious.

description.p: At 13th level, your understanding of the nature of reality extends to the creatures around you. At the end of a long rest, you can designate a number of friendly creatures equal to your Wisdom modifier. They gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws until the end of their next long rest.
If the target of this ability already has proficiency in Wisdom saving throws, they gain proficiency in Intelligence or Charisma saving throws instead.

sheet.description: At the end of a long rest, you can designate up to {{wisdom:modifier}} friendly creatures. They gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws until the end of their next long rest. If the target of this ability already has proficiency in Wisdom saving throws, they gain proficiency in Intelligence or Charisma saving throws instead.

description.p: At 17th level, your mastery over the nature of reality ascends beyond the mundane and into the language of the multiverse itself. When you finish a long rest, you focus your mind and learn one Power Word. As an action on your turn, you speak the Power Word aloud, and the spell of the same name takes effect as if cast by you.

Choose one of the following spells; power word heal, power word kill, power word pain, or power word stun. You can use this ability once per long rest at no cost. Every additional time you use it after the first, you gain one level of exhaustion.

sheet.description: When you finish a long rest, you focus your mind and learn one Power Word. As an action on your turn, you speak the Power Word aloud, and the spell of the same name takes effect as if cast by you. Choose one of the following spells; power word heal, power word kill, power word pain, or power word stun. You can use this ability once per long rest at no cost. Every additional time you use it after the first, you gain one level of exhaustion.

description.p: For all of history, there have been those who study how living things work. Clerics and priests of gods of life and healing, necromancers and liches who seek to raise the dead, and deadly assassins and warriors who learn the most vulnerable points to strike. Unlike all of these, the Physicians of the world use knowledge and mundane science to heal wounds, cure disease, and improve the quality of life for those that cannot afford the luxury of magical healing.

Physicians are specialists who have focused their research on the body. Primarily, how it functions and how to repair it when damaged. Physicians do not rely on divine or arcane magic to heal, but through a combination of knowledge, focus, and precision they dress wounds, perform surgeries, and save lives.

When you choose to become a Physician at 3rd level you dedicate yourself to the art of healing. When you choose this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency with the herbalism kit and the medicine skill. If you already have either of these proficiencies you gain expertise, which means you add double your proficiency bonus to any medicine checks you make. When you make a check with either of the proficiencies gained from this ability you may use your Intelligence modifier in place of Wisdom.

Additionally, your specialized training allows you to utilize mundane healing equipment to it's fullest potential. When you stabilize a creature with a healer's kit, your knowledge allows you to stimulate additional healing. Upon use, the creature regains hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier.

sheet.description: When you make a Medicine or Herbalism Kit check you may use your Intelligence modifier in place of Wisdom. Additionally, when you stabilize a creature with a healer's kit, the creature regains {{intelligence:modifier}} hit points.

element.name: Student of Medicine: Herbalism Kit Proficiency
Student of Medicine: Herbalism Kit Expertise

sheet.description: You double your proficiency when making a check using an Herbalism kit.

description.p: At 3rd level you gain the following medical actions:

Adrenaline Boost. Touch a friendly creature and expend one or more Intellect Points, up to your mental limit. The creature immediately gains temporary hit points equal to five times the number of Intellect Points you expend.
Dress Wounds. Touch a friendly creature and expend one or more Intellect Points, up to your mental limit. The creature immediately regains 1d6 hit points for each Intellect Point you expend.

Healing Surge. You can stimulate natural healing in one creature you touch. Touch a creature, and as a free action, the creature can expend one of their hit die and regain hit points equal to the roll + their Constitution modifier.

sheet.description: You have the following medical actions: Adrenaline Boost, Dress Wounds, and Healing Surge.

description.p: At 9th level your focus on keeping your allies in top condition allows you to move about the battlefield unscathed. If you use your action to use a healer's kit, herbalism kit, or any of the actions you gained from your Combat Medic ability, you are under the effects of the Dodge action until the beginning of your next turn, and your movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

sheet.description: If you use your action to use a healer's kit, herbalism kit, or any of the actions you gained from your Combat Medic ability, you are under the effects of the Dodge action until the beginning of your next turn, and your movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

description.p: At 13th level your knowledge has advanced to the point that you can stave off death itself, if only for a time. As an action you can touch a creature that has died within the last minute and attempt to resuscitate them as if casting the revivify spell.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier. You regain all uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: You can touch a creature that has died within the last minute and attempt to resuscitate them as if casting the revivify spell.

description.p: By 17th level your knowledge of medicine is peerless. When one of your abilities heals a friendly creature or grants them temporary hit points, they gain additional hit points equal to your savant level.
Additionally, any hit dice expended during a short rest with you are treated as their maximum roll.

sheet.description: When one of your abilities heals a friendly creature or grants them temporary hit points, they gain {{level:savant}} additional hit points. Additionally, any hit dice expended during a short rest with you are treated as their maximum roll.

description.p: Every successful king, conquerer, or rebellion has a master strategist that is directly responsible for their success in battle. Tacticians are always thinking one step ahead of their enemies, and have a plan for every eventuality. They focus on the big picture, ensuring that they not only win each battle, but the war itself.

You have spent your time studying the art of war and long forgotten histories of conquest and glory. You know the strategies that lead to glory, and those that end in ruin. Alone you are no threat, but with powerful allies to command, you are a force to be reckoned with.

Starting at 3rd level when you dedicate yourself to this Academic Discipline you gain the skills necessary to lead others on the battlefield. Your time studying the histories of kingdoms and wars long forgotten grants you proficiency in the history skill. If you already have proficiency in history you gain expertise, which means you add double your proficiency bonus to any history checks you make. Unlike other savants, you have spent some of your time preparing to directly engage in battle. You gain proficiency in medium armor and all martial weapons that lack the heavy property.
Additionally, when you deal damage to an enemy creature with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to use your Savant's Analysis ability targeting the creature you damaged.

sheet.description: When you deal damage to an enemy creature with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to use your Savant's Analysis ability targeting the creature you damaged.

description.p: At 3rd level, allied creatures have come to respect you enough to listen to your commands on the battlefield. As an action on your turn, you can expend an Intellect Point to issue a command to a friendly creature. They must be within 30 ft. and be able to see or hear you. The next time the friendly creature takes the attack action they make an additional attack. The additional attack must be made before the beginning of your next turn.

Starting at 9th level, as an action, you may to expend up to two Intellect Points to issue two commands, at 13th level you can expend three Intellect Points to issue three commands, and finally at 17th level, you can expend four Intellect Points to issue four commands. You cannot target the same creature with more then one command.

sheet.description: You can issue a command to a friendly creature. They must be within 30 ft. and be able to see or hear you. The next time the friendly creature takes the attack action they make an additional attack. The additional attack must be made before the beginning of your next turn.

You can up to two commands to two friendly creatures. They must be within 30 ft. and be able to see or hear you. The next time the friendly creature takes the attack action they make an additional attack. The additional attack must be made before the beginning of your next turn.

You can up to three commands to three friendly creatures. They must be within 30 ft. and be able to see or hear you. The next time the friendly creature takes the attack action they make an additional attack. The additional attack must be made before the beginning of your next turn.

You can up to four commands to four friendly creatures. They must be within 30 ft. and be able to see or hear you. The next time the friendly creature takes the attack action they make an additional attack. The additional attack must be made before the beginning of your next turn.

description.p: At 9th level, your position as a leader does not afford you the comfort of succumbing to your base instincts, and you have studied methods to steel your mind against certain debilitating effects. You are immune to the charmed and frightened conditions, and any friendly creatures within 15 ft. of you have advantage on saving throws against the charmed and frightened conditions.

sheet.description: You are immune to the charmed and frightened conditions, and any friendly creatures within 15 ft. of you have advantage on saving throws against the charmed and frightened conditions.

description.p: At 13th level, when an allied creature within 15 ft. of you is targeted with an weapon attack, spell attack, or forced to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to issue a defensive command. Any conscious friendly creature within 15 ft., that can see or hear you gains the benefits of three quarters cover until the beginning of your next turn.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier. You regain all uses when you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: When an allied creature within 15 ft. of you is targeted with an weapon attack, spell attack, or forced to make a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to issue a defensive command. Any conscious friendly creature within 15 ft., that can see or hear you gains the benefits of three quarters cover until the beginning of your next turn.

description.p: At 17th level your tactical mind ranks among the greatest commanders of history, and your ability to spot weakness in your foes is unmatched. When you target an enemy creature with your Discerning Strike ability, the first attack that targets that creature before the beginning of your next turn has advantage.

Additionally, your commands bolster your allies resolve. Any friendly creature that is targeted by either your Strategic or Defensive Commands immediately gains temporary hit points equal to your savant level + your Intelligence modifier.

sheet.description: When you target an enemy creature with your Discerning Strike ability, the first attack that targets that creature before the beginning of your next turn has advantage. Additionally, any friendly creature that is targeted by either your Strategic or Defensive Commands immediately gains {{master-tactician:temp-hp}} temporary hit points.
